November 30, 2008: Fiction
THE CHRISTMAS SWEATER, by Glenn Beck with Kevin Balfe and Jason Wright.
(Threshold Editions, $19.99.) A boy learns from his disappointment with his
mother’s gift.
JUST AFTER SUNSET, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) Short stories blending
fantasy and psychological realism.
DIVINE JUSTICE, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.) Members of
Washington’s Camel Club rally to save their leader, who is hiding out in the town
of Divine, Va.
THE HOUR I FIRST BELIEVED, by Wally Lamb. (Harper, $29.95.) A man
reconstructs five generations of family history and secrets from a cache of old
diaries and letters.
A MERCY, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $23.95.) In 17th-century America, a slave
mother urges a Northern farmer to buy her daughter so that she can have a better
life.
THE GATE HOUSE, by Nelson DeMille. (Grand Central, $27.99.) In a sequel to
“The Gold Coast” (1990) a tax attorney and his ex-wife explore a reconciliation.
EXTREME MEASURES, by Vince Flynn. (Atria, $27.95.) Mitch Rapp teams up
with a C.I.A. colleague to fight a terrorist cell — and the politicians who would rein
them in.
SALVATION IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $25.95.) Lt. Eve Dallas
investigates the murder of a mysterious priest; by Nora Roberts, writing
pseudonymously.
THE LUCKY ONE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Grand Central, $24.99.) A marine
returning home sets out to track down the woman whose photo he found in Iraq.
SWALLOWING DARKNESS, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Ballantine, $26.) In the
seventh Meredith Gentry paranormal romance, Meredith is pregnant with twins.
THE STORY OF EDGAR SAWTELLE, by David Wroblewski. (Ecco, $25.95.) A
mute takes refuge with three dogs in the Wisconsin woods after his father’s death.
THE BRASS VERDICT, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $26.) Harry Bosch
and Mickey Haller (the Lincoln lawyer) team up to find a killer.
THE BODIES LEFT BEHIND, by Jeffery Deaver. (Simon & Schuster, $26.95.) A
sheriff’s deputy is hunted in the Wisconsin woods by hit men after she finds the
scene of their crime.
MIDNIGHT, by Sister Souljah. (Atria, $26.95.) A boy from Sudan struggles to
November 30, 2008
Non-Fiction
TOO FAT TO FISH, by Artie Lange with Anthony Bozza. (Spiegel & Grau, $24.95.)
Humorous memories from the comedian, a member of the cast of “The Howard
Stern Show.”
AMERICAN LION, by Jon Meacham. (Random House, $30.) Andrew Jackson, the
seventh president, in the White House, by the editor of Newsweek.
DEWEY, by Vicki Myron with Bret Witter. (Grand Central, $19.99.) The kitten left
freezing in the returned-book slot of an Iowa public library and his rise to fame.
HOT, FLAT, AND CROWDED, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$27.95.) How a green revolution can renew America, by the New York Times
columnist.
THE SNOWBALL, by Alice Schroeder. (Bantam, $35.) The life of Warren Buffett.
A BOLD FRESH PIECE OF HUMANITY, by Bill O’Reilly. (Broadway, $26.) The
Fox News commentator on his upbringing and career.
THE AMERICAN JOURNEY OF BARACK OBAMA, by the editors of Life
magazine. (Little, Brown, $24.99.) Photographs and essays, starting with Obama’s
birth in Hawaii.
CALL ME TED, by Ted Turner with Bill Burke. (Grand Central, $30.) The
entrepreneur’s personal story.
LETTER TO MY DAUGHTER, by Maya Angelou. (Random House, $25.)
Reminiscences, appreciations and poems from the author of “I Know Why the
Caged Bird Sings.”
DREAMS FROM MY FATHER, by Barack Obama. (Crown, $25.95.) The
president-elect on life as the son of a black African father and a white American
mother.
THE AUDACITY OF HOPE, by Barack Obama. (Crown, $25.) The president-elect
asks Americans to move beyond political divisions.
FLEECED, by Dick Morris and Eileen McGann. (Harper, $26.95.) Americans are
fleeced by government, business, labor unions and lobbyists.
AGAINST MEDICAL ADVICE, by James Patterson and Hal Friedman. (Little,
Brown, $26.99.) A family’s struggle to get treatment for their son’s Tourette’s
syndrome.
MY STROKE OF INSIGHT, by Jill Bolte Taylor. (Viking, $24.95.) A brain scientist
shares what she learned from her 1996 stroke.
